title: Don't Think of Lissandra as an 'Anti-Hero'...
body:
Think of her more as a 'lesser of two evils' compared to that of the Watchers. She was obviously an ambitious, somewhat power hungry woman for making a deal with the Watchers to grant herself magical abilities and immortality, but she obviously knew the true threat of the Void (something that Malzahar seemingly embraces or outright is unaware of).

She is still the same Ice Witch who manipulates Freljordian history for her own benefit from within the shadows, only she does it for herself now rather than for the Watchers. The fact that she fears the Watchers so much and is so active in keeping them imprisoned only emphasizes how big of a threat they are, maybe even as the *true* 'big-bad' of League's universe.

replies.body: Isn't this the exact definition of an anti-hero? They do bad things for good reasons. That is an anti-hero.

> Isn't this the exact definition of an anti-hero? They do bad things for good reasons. That is an anti-hero.

Anti-Villain.

Anti-villains are typically bad guys either because of affiliation or being a lesser danger.


For example, an anti-villain could be a baddy who is only considered a bad guy because he wants to protect his friends who happen to be evil.  He is otherwise a good person with redeeming traits, but...he is with the bad guys.


Then there's the villain who is only seen as good because they are in direct conflict with another villain.  Lissandra is definitely a bad guy. She vies for power. Murders, manipulates, and isn't doing anything genuinely benign.  She is against the Frozen Watchers not to SAVE the world, but so she can KEEP it.  She wants to rule Runeterra, but she can't do it if she lets the Watchers and the Void destroy it.


That is why she "appears" as a good guy.  Because she is dealing with a greater evil.  Otherwise, yeah.  She's an Anti-villain.

Technically, an anti-hero is just any protagonist that is placed in the role of a hero but lacks any of the standard heroic traits of the culture that makes the character.

The bad things for good reasons is one variant, pure villain protagonists are another, and the schmuck hero is another.

EDIT: plus all the other things other people have already replied, and which are more relevant to the discussion as a whole. I just wanted to point out the small mistake in your reasoning ;)

"For good reasons".

It's mainly for her own survival rather than for some benevolent ideal.

> It's mainly for her own survival rather than for some benevolent ideal.

Although there are some this element,I don't desire her to be a pathetic person inviting pity.
In addition to it I want it is for her own overweening ambition.

Eh there are many definitions of Anti-hero,though what you describe is more like an anti-villain(a villain who has either good motivations or personality traits).

However I think Lissandra can qualify as both an Anti-villain(because she still antagonizes Ashe and Sejuani) and an Anti-hero(because she is working for the greater good).

And tbh,I think that when it comes to Lissandra as an Anti-Hero I'd say she likely falls more specifically into the category of a nominal hero(more or less the worst kind of anti-hero), a hero who is neutral at best and evil at worst,but who is considered a hero,because they oppose the greater villains as well.

Lissandra only wants to conquer the world herself! She is a villain character but as you said shes the lesser evil... 
She doesnt want the watchers so consume her world which she wants to dominate one day so she took advantage of them by making her Iceborn and then she imprisoned them :)

I'm glad she realized that the Void's coming would kill her too, unlike most "otherworldly doom" heralds.

It would degrade her intelligence.

Agree.  Yeah, that’s a pet peeve of mine in fantasy fiction.  Lissandra here was smart enough and unscrupulous enough  to play both sides. 
But even as a villian she found that being responsible for killing your own family— is not a crime she could just wipe her hands of— which is also metaphorically represented by her relationship with the watchers.

Well, in most good stories, they at least acknowledge that trope and the "herald" think they will be saved, or put in charge, or something like that. Now, how can they be so stupid or crazy to believe that, that's a tougher question, and not so many works address it convincingly (some do, though), but very few works ignore the topic entirely nowadays, I feel.

Still, it's nice to see the trope not only acknowledged, but subverted entirely. Props to you. :)
